awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Institute for Hybrid Quantum Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields.
 
This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal along the theme of quantum transduction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the conceptualization phase, several clear, high-impact challenges in quantum transduction where identified through a series of in person and virtual workshops bringing together more than 45 investigators and 18 students over a two year timeframe. This included both the need for interfaces between hybrid qubit systems, the need for spin-based testbeds, materials and device user facilities and new training labs at the high-school through undergraduate level. The concept of an NV-based quantum control testbed was launched which was later established at the University of Washington. The Quantum Technologies Training and Testbed (QT3) Lab was conceived under this award, attracting a further $2.5M federal investment to give researchers access to quantum characterization tools, students hands-on labs, and build two small-scale qubit testbeds. 

Undergraduate student researchers contributed to the instrument development of the quantum light microscope in the QT3 lab and the tool has been used for two on-boarding courses in the NSF STC: Center for Integration of Mdern Optoelectronic Materials. In each onboarding course, 30 graduate students and postdocs from interest areas raning from materials to devices to theory conduct hands-on single photon correlation measurements and analysize their results. The QT3 user facility is expected to advance materials development for quantum technologies for many years to come.
